cluster_relations.rel_desc: The egg stage is behaviorally positioned to avoid predators by being laid under leaves.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: when located on underside of leaves
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Mechanism: concealed placement reduces predation risk

remarks: Relation primarily to capture the protective intent against predators.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillar spines function to protect caterpillars from their predators.
remarks: Predators are not explicitly named in this sentence but are referenced later; relation inferred.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillar hairs serve as protective structures against predators.
remarks: As with spines, predators are implied rather than explicitly named in this clause.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Twig mimicry behavior helps caterpillars avoid detection by predators.
Leaf mimicry behavior helps caterpillars hide from predators.
The chrysalis functions as a protective shell surrounding the caterpillar.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject trait or behavior confers anti-predator protection by reducing the risk or effectiveness of attacks from the predator entity given as the object.
args.justification: All five relations describe morphological or behavioral adaptations (egg placement, spines, hairs, twig mimicry, leaf mimicry) that function to protect the organism from predators named as the object; a single predicate specifically capturing anti-predator protection improves consistency.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject provides physical or functional protection for the object over some period or context.
args.justification: This relation describes the chrysalis acting as a protective shell around the caterpillar itself, not specifically an anti-predator interaction; a more general protection predicate is appropriate and distinct from predator-focused edges.

All relations describe traits or structures whose functional role is to protect an organism (egg or caterpillar) from harm, so they naturally belong to a shared class of protective function relations even though one predicate is predator-specific and the other is general.
In each case, the subject causally brings about a reduction in risk or harm to the organism (protective effect), so the broad semantic dimension is causal (trait/structure causes protection).
